required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A 4-Day Study to Evaluate the Photoxicity of Diacerein 1% Topical Ointment in Healthy Volunteers
clinical_study.official_title: A 4 Day, Randomized Study to Evaluate the Potential of CCP-020 (Diacerein 1%) Topical Ointment to Induce a Phototoxicity Skin Reaction in Healthy Subjects, Using a Controlled Photopatch Test

brief_summary.textblock: This study was designed to assess the phototoxic potential of diacerein 1% ointment when application is followed by light exposure.

detailed_description.textblock:
This was a single-center, randomized, within-subject comparison of diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment applied to 2 sites on opposite sides of the the infrascapular area of the back under occlusive patch conditions for approximately 24 (±2) hours. Product was applied according to the randomization scheme in an amount of 0.2 mL, once during the study.
Patches were removed and 1 of the skin sites for each product was irradiated and 1 remained non-irradiated. The irradiated and non-irradiated sites were compared with each other and with an untreated irradiated control site.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Phototoxicity Potential Assessment (Photopatch test). All subjects received applications of 0.2 mL of diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment under occlusive patch conditions to 2 skin sites at the infrascapular area of the back for approximately 24 (±2) hours. Following the removal of the patches, one site was irradiated and one remained non-irradiated.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Days 3 and 4 (24 and 48 hours post site irradiation procedure)
primary_outcome.description: The mean of the total irritation scores 24 and 48 hours post the site irradiation procedure. ( i.e. Day 3 and 4) Total Irritation Score is a visual score summing the degree of erythema and edema. Minimum score= 0; Maximum score = 5; higher score = worse outcome.

intervention.description: Diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment were applied on Day 1 at two randomly assigned skin sites on each side of the lower thoracic area of the back according to a randomization scheme. One side of the back was irradiated on Day 2, including an untreated irradiated control site, and the other side was to remain non-irradiated.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Single Cohort (Healthy Volunteers)
group.description: Diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment were applied on Day 1 at two randomly assigned skin sites on each side of the lower thoracic area of the back according to a randomization scheme. One side of the back was irradiated on Day 2, including an untreated irradiated control site, and the other side was to remain non-irradiated.

One side of the back was irradiated on Day 2, including an untreated irradiated control site, and the other side was to remain non-irradiated.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Observed Phototoxicity
outcome.description: The mean of the total irritation scores 24 and 48 hours post the site irradiation procedure. ( i.e. Day 3 and 4) Total Irritation Score is a visual score summing the degree of erythema and edema. Minimum score= 0; Maximum score = 5; higher score = worse outcome.
outcome.time_frame: Days 3 and 4 (24 and 48 hours post site irradiation procedure)
outcome.population: 5 skin sites on each of 34 participants for a total of 170 skin sites evaluated.

group.title: Single Cohort (Healthy Volunteer)
group.description: Diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment were applied on Day 1 at two randomly assigned skin sites on each side of the lower thoracic area of the back according to a randomization scheme. One side of the back was irradiated on Day 2, including an untreated irradiated control site, and the other side was to remain non-irradiated.

measure.title: Observed Phototoxicity
measure.description: The mean of the total irritation scores 24 and 48 hours post the site irradiation procedure. ( i.e. Day 3 and 4) Total Irritation Score is a visual score summing the degree of erythema and edema. Minimum score= 0; Maximum score = 5; higher score = worse outcome.
measure.population: 5 skin sites on each of 34 participants for a total of 170 skin sites evaluated.

analysis.groups_desc: Irradiated vehicle and untreated irradiated sites versus irradiated diacerein site, and non-irradiated vehicle site versus non-irradiated diacerein site and untreated irradiated site versus irradiated vehicle site.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: p-values are from an ANOVA of the average numerical score (sum of erythema and edema) at 24 and 48 hours post irradiation (Days 3 and 4) with effects of subject and treatment, using Fisher's least significant differences.

analysis.groups_desc: Non-irradiated diacerein and vehicle sites versus irradiated diacerein site, and irradiated vehicle and untreated irradiated sites versus non-irradiated diacerein site, and non-irradiated vehicle site versus irradiated vehicle site, and untreated irradiated site versus non-irradiated vehicle site.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: p-values are from an ANOVA of the average numerical score (sum of erythema and edema) at 24 and 48 hours post irradiation (Days 3 and 4) with effects of subject and treatment, using Fisher's least significant differences.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse Events (AEs) were to be reported from first dose through completion of the last study visit (i.e. Four days).
reported_events.desc: Adverse events were not assessed at a patch site-specific level.

group.title: Single Cohort (Healthy Volunteers)
group.description: Diacerein 1% ointment and vehicle ointment were applied on Day 1 at two randomly assigned skin sites on each side of the lower thoracic area of the back according to a randomization scheme. One side of the back was irradiated on Day 2, including an untreated irradiated control site, and the other side was to remain non-irradiated.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: There were no limitations or caveats in this trial.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Dr. Mary Spellman; Chief Medical Officer
